questions.question: Which of the following is the second most common malignancy in childhood?
The MRI scan of an 11-year-old girl revealed a brain tumor. In which of the followingconditions would you do a lumbar puncture for cytological analysis?
questions.explanation: Germ-cell tumor is an indication for lumbar puncture for cytological analysis of CSF.Usually, lumbar punctures are contraindicated in intracranial space-occupying lesions with highintracranial pressure as it can lead to brain herniation and death. They are thus delayed until676surgery or shunt placement. However, in tumors with a risk of leptomeningeal metastases, lumbarpuncture is indicated for cytology.Tumors where LP is indicateTumors where LP is contraindicateddMedulloblastoma or primitive neuroectodermal tumorsEpendymomaGerm cell tumorsInfratentorialtumorsSupratentorialtumors withmidline shiftTumors withhydrocephalussecondary toCSF obstruction

questions.question: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to the hospital with sudden onset vomiting. She hasalso been noticing an alarming increase in the head size of the baby. On examination,significant macrocephaly is seen. MRI reveals a supratentorial tumor. Which of the followingtumors is the most likely cause of this child's presentation?
questions.explanation: Choroid plexus carcinoma is a pediatric supratentorial tumor presenting with macrocephaly andfocal neurologic deficits.Choroid plexus tumors are the most common CNS tumors in children aged less than 1 year. Thesetumors are intraventricular epithelial neoplasms arising from the choroid plexus.Children present with signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), whereasinfants may present with macrocephaly and focal neurologic deficits.Medulloblastoma, pilocytic astrocytoma, and ependymoma, are all predominantly infratentorialtumors.The age-related differences in the primary location of the tumor are given below:AgePredominant SExamplesite< 1 yearSupratentorialChoroid plexus tumor and teratoma1 - 10 yearInfratentorialSJuvenile pilocytic astrocytoma and medulloblastoma> 10 yearsSupratentorialDiffuse astrocytoma

questions.question: 661Sanam, a 7-year-old kid is suspected to have an ependymoma. Which of the following featureson histopathology would favor this diagnosis?

options.B: Perivascular pseudorosettesFlexner-Wintersteiner rosettesd) Homer-Wright rosettesQuestion 5:A young child was evaluated for increased ICP. A brain tumor was found on an MRI scan. Itwas resected and sent for histopathological examination. The slide is shown below. Thistumor is found most commonly in thea) Filum terminaleb) Pia mater

questions.explanation: Perivascular rosettes will be seen on histopathological examination of ependymoma. Otherfeatures include ependymal rosettes and monomorphic nuclear morphology.Ependymomas are tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system occurringpredominantly in childhood. They are usually non-invasive, extending into the ventricular lumenand/or displacing normal structures, sometimes leading to significant obstructive hydrocephalus.677

questions.question: A concerned mother brought her daughter to the clinic for evaluation of symptoms that haveworsened in the last few weeks. The daughter frequently wakes up at night with severeheadaches and vomiting. She has also been having some difficulty walking. On examination,ataxia and multiple cranial nerve palsies are noted. Imaging is suggestive of a brainstem662tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The MRI given shows a diffuse, infiltrating pontine lesion. Multiple cranial nerve dysfunctions,cerebellar signs, motor weakness, and features of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) are allstrongly suggestive of a pontine glioma.These are not amenable for surgical resection. The standard approach is radiation therapy. Theprognosis is very poor.

questions.question: On your neurology rotation, you come across Ashu, a 5-year-old child who presented with a6-month history of ataxia, headaches, and vomiting. He was admitted to the ward for furtherevaluation. MRI scan showed a brain tumor with a combination of solid and cysticcomponents. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. Which of the following isthe most likely diagnosis?663
questions.explanation: The given slide shows condensed masses of glial filaments occurring in compact areas suggestiveof Rosenthal fibers. The clinical features, MRI findings, and histopathology point towards adiagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.Pilocytic astrocytoma is a low-grade astrocytoma tumor. It is the most common type ofastrocytoma in children. These are classically found in the cerebellum (infratentorial) and theoptic pathway regions.There is usually a 3-6 month history of limb ataxia, secondary headaches, and vomiting. Muralnodule, a contrast medium enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass is seen on MRI.The tumor has a low metastatic potential and is rarely invasive.

questions.question: What is the WHO grading for Pilomyxoid astrocytoma?
questions.explanation: Pilomyxoid astrocytoma falls under WHO Grade II. Pilomyxoid astrocytoma: Occurs most commonly in the hypothalamic/optic chiasmic region and carries a high risk of local as well as cerebrospinal spread. This astrocytoma affects young children and infants. It is classified as a WHO Grade II tumor. WHO Grades of brain tumors: WHO grade - Grade I, Grade II, Grade III, Grade IV. Example: Pilocytic astrocytoma, Myxopapillary Ependymoma/subependymoma, Diffuse astrocytoma, Pilomyxoid astrocytoma, Papillary/ cellular/Clear-cell ependymoma, Anaplastic astrocytoma, Anaplastic ependymoma, Glioblastoma multiforme, Malignant pineoblastoma and medulloblastoma.

questions.question: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells andHomer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgeryresident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumorwas present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?664
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma.Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermisthat causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus andoften metastasizes extraneurally.Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized byHomer-Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin.Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinalradiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the timeof diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene.Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristicappearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue onroutine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are:• Medulloblastoma●Neuroblastoma• Retinoblastoma•Ewing's sarcoma•Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.question: A child is brought to the emergency department by his teacher when he started havingabnormal jerking movements during math class. The parents give a history of the childhaving similar episodes in the past. On the way to the CT room, the child had an episode ofseizure and was stabilized with lorazepam. The imaging done is shown below. What is themost likely diagnosis?665
questions.explanation: 679Calcified cortical mass with a seizure is suggestive of oligodendroglioma.Oligodendrogliomas are uncommon tumors of childhood. These infiltrating tumors occurpredominantly in the cerebral cortex and originate in white matter. Treatment involves surgicalresection followed by involved field radiation therapy.The image below shows histology of oligodendroglioma showing characteristic fried eggappearance and chicken wire capillaries.OligodendrogliomaOMARROW-Craniopharyngioma is associated with suprasellar calcification. Also, the childwith a history of endocrinological and visual complaints.mayoften present

questions.question: An erythropoietin-secreting brain tumor is detected in a child. His father passed away oneyear back from end-stage renal cell carcinoma. Family history is significant for VHLmutation. On examination, a fiery red retina is seen. Which of the following is the most likelytumor present in this child?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cerebellar hemangioblastoma.Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. The major neurologicalfeatures of VHL include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas.Cerebellar hemangioblastomas are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead topolycythemia. It typically appears as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CTor MRI scan.Retinal angiomas are small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheralretina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascularmass. It can lead to retinal detachment and visual loss.680#3Associations of VHL syndrome include:•••• Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymisRenal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death)Pheochromocytoma•Cerebellar hemangioblastoma• Retinal angioma

questions.question: Akhil, a 15-year-old boy with sun-setting eyes, has a tumor in the pineal region as seen in theMRI. Parinaud syndrome is suspected. Which of the following findings will not be seen in thisboy?sel90D1 SATTR530.0TE14.0/1TA04:38AC2KM I.V.

options.C: Convergence retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze

questions.explanation: Parinaud's syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder.Parinaud's syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posteriorcommissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis.Causes:•Pineal region or midbrain tumors (Most common cause)• Neurocysticercosis•Stroke• Multiple sclerosisFeatures include the following:• Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved)• Convergence-retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze• Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign• Lid retraction- Collier's sign681• Pseudo-Argyll-Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilatedand show light-near dissociation• Bilateral papilledema• Skew deviation•Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.question: An 8-year-old child is brought to the casualty after a minor accident that occurred when hefailed to see a bike coming from sideways. His mother says he is a clumsy child, whosometimes knocks things over accidentally even at home. Visual field examination findingsare given below. On imaging, an intracranial mass is seen. The resected specimen showscholesterol-rich machinery-oil-like fluid. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Patients with adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma present with bitemporal hemianopia(image), and the cystic component of this tumor contains a cholesterol-rich, thick,brownish-yellow fluid that is comparable to "machine oil."Craniopharyngiomas develop from remnants of the Rathke pouch. Adamantinomatous variant ofcraniopharyngioma predominates in childhood.These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous, displaying both solid and cystic components,and occur in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with headache and visual fieldabnormalities. These children also have endocrinological abnormalities such as growth failure anddelayed sexual maturation due to hypopituitarism (GH deficiency).These tumors are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulfnormal brain structures. CT may show calcifications associated with the solid and cysticcomponents.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common extracranial solid tumor in the pediatric agegroup?
questions.explanation: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children and the most commonlydiagnosed malignancy in infants. It is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral nervous system.The signs and symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and the extent of the disease.Neuroblastomas originating from the superior cervical ganglion can present with Hornersyndrome.Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following• Fever• Irritability• Failure to thrive.• Bone pain•Cytopenia• Bluish subcutaneous nodules• Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymosesRapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus),and ataxia are characteristic of the opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is682a paraneoplastic syndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastomas.Some neuroblastomas may undergo spontaneous regression, whereas some may be unresponsiveto therapy and run a very aggressive course.Age groupCalcificationsMarginsVascular invasionRelation with surrounding structuresNeuroblastoma<2 years of ageVery common (90%)Poorly marginatedEncases vascular structures but does not invade themElevates the aorta away fromthe vertebral columnCommonly crosses the midline, especially behind the aortaWilm's tumor (nephroblastoma)Peaks at 3-4 years of ageUncommon (10-15%)Well circumscribedExtends into the IVC and renal veinDisplaces adjacent structureswithout insinuating betweenthemForms the claw sign with the kidney

questions.question: A 5-year-old child presents with rapid dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking of limbs andpoor coordination. You suspect a paraneoplastic syndrome. Which of the following conditionsshould you look for in this child?
questions.explanation: Rapid dancing eye movements (opsoclonus), rhythmic jerking of limbs/trunk (myoclonus) andataxia is characteristic of opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome (OMA). It is a paraneoplasticsyndrome of autoimmune origin with a strong association with neuroblastoma.All children with OMA should undergo investigations for neuroblastoma such as ultrasoundfollowed by CT or MRI of chest and abdomen, bone scans and marrow biopsies. The definitivediagnosis of neuroblastoma is through biopsy which shows small round blue cells.Other small round blue cell tumours are medulloblastoma, retinoblastoma, Ewing's sarcoma andrhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.question: In the ophthalmology OPD, you see a 3-year-old child with the following finding. There is nohistory of trauma. There is no significant family history. Which of the following is the mostlikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This image shows periorbital ecchymoses and proptosis suggestive of metastases ofneuroblastoma (a sign of orbital bone involvement).Neuroblastomas may develop at any site in the sympathetic nervous system. Metastatic spread iscommon in children who are diagnosed after 1 year of age. It occurs via local invasion,hematogenous, or lymphatic routes.Metastatic disease can cause a variety of signs and symptoms, including the following:• Fever•Irritability•Failure to thrive• Bone pain683•Cytopenia• Bluish subcutaneous nodules• Orbital proptosis, and periorbital ecchymoses

questions.question: A 10-month-old infant is diagnosed with neuroblastoma. Which of the following factors isassociated with a good prognosis?
questions.explanation: Hyperdiploidy is associated with a good prognosis in neuroblastoma if the child is younger than 1year of age at diagnosis.Bad prognosis in neuroblastoma is seen in cases of:•Amplification of N-MYC• Loss of Heterozygosiy of 1p, 11 q,14q•⚫ Gain of 17q• TrkB expression

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of an enlarging scalp lesion. There is nohistory of trauma to the head or scalp. The child is otherwise healthy and investigations arenormal. X-ray of the head is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the x-ray image showing a punched-out lytic lesion is suggestive ofLangerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).LCH is a rare histiocytic disorder characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions thatcan infiltrate nearly every organ, most notably the skin (of the scalp), lungs, thymus, liver, spleen,bone marrow, or the central nervous system.LCH is so named because of its resemblance to the Langerhan's cells, which are specializeddendritic cells found in the skin and mucosa.

questions.question: A 12-year-old child is brought with 4 small, purplish, rubbery lesions on his back and arms.On examination, you note inguinal freckling and nodules on the iris as shown below. Which669chromosome is involved in the syndrome described in this child?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1. The NF1 gene onchromosome 17q11 is involved. It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome.It is diagnosed when at least 2 of the following 7 criteria are met:•• 6 or more cafe-au-lait macules.• >5mm prepuberty•>15mm post-puberty•Skin-fold freckling- axillary and inguinal• 2 or more iris lisch nodules (image)• 2 or more neurofibromas or 1 plexiform neurofibroma (purplish, rubbery lesions)684• Osseous lesions• Osseous dysplasia••Cortical thinning of long bones without a pseudoarthrosis•Low-grade astrocytomas like optic gliomas• 1st degree relative with diagnosed NF-1

questions.question: Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNSmanifestations of
questions.explanation: Vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and spinal cord ependymomas are the CNSmanifestations of neurofibromatosis type 2It is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due to a mutation in theNF2 gene on chromosome 22q12.von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occursdue to a mutation in the VHL gene on chromosome 3p25-26. The CNS manifestation is usually ahemangioblastoma.Turcot syndrome is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome, which occurs due toa mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5q21. The CNS manifestation is a medulloblastoma.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presented with focal seizures involving the right side of his body. Oninvestigations, a subependymal giant cell astrocytoma is found. Which of the followingsyndromes is most likely to be associated with this?
questions.explanation: Subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma is a characteristic CNS finding in tuberous sclerosis.SyndromeCNS ManifestationsGeneNeurofibromatosis type 1(aut Optic pathway gliomas AstrocNF1osomal dominant)ytomaMalignant peripheral nerve sheath tumoursNeurofibromasosomal dominant)Von Hippel-Lindau(autosomal dominant)Neurofibromatosis type 2(aut Vestibular schwannomasMenNF2ingiomasSpinal cord ependymomasCerebellar hemangioblastomVHLaTuberous Sclerosis (autosoma Subependymal giant-cell astr1 dominant)Turcot syndrome (autosomaldominant)ocytomaCortical tubersMedulloblastomaGlioblastomTSC1TSC2APCa

questions.question: What is the most common intraocular tumor diagnosed in the pediatric age group?
questions.explanation: 685Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular tumor of the pediatric age group. It is anembryonal malignancy of the retina.

questions.question: James was brought by his mother for evaluation of a squint she noticed. On examination, thegiven finding was observed. Investigations revealed retinoblastoma with a germline RB1 genemutation. The secondary malignancy most likely to develop in him is:
questions.explanation: Children with germline RB1 mutations are at significant risk for the development of secondarymalignancies, especially•Osteosarcoma (Most common)Soft tissue sarcomas• Malignant melanomaThe risk of secondary malignancies is further increased by the use of radiation therapy.A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called 'trilateralretinoblastoma'.The image shows leukocoria, a white pupillary reflex. It may be seen in the following conditions:Congenital cataract•• Retinoblastoma• Retinopathy of prematurity (retrolental fibroplasia)• Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous• Coats disease•Toxocara endophthalmitis

questions.question: 671A 5-year-old boy presented with an abdominal mass. On examination, the mass is firm,smooth, non-tender, and does not cross the mid-line. The boy is also found to have moderatehypertension. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria. Wilms tumor is suspected. Thiscondition can be associated with all of the following except
questions.explanation: Polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilm's tumor.Wilms tumor (WT), also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renaltumor of childhood.Polycystic kidney disease can also present with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria.However, there will be multiple irregular cysts on ultrasound and is not associated with Wilmstumor.

questions.question: You are assisting on a left partial nephrectomy in a child with Wilms tumor. Intraoperatively,a small mass is noted on the right kidney as well. Frozen section reveals it to be a Wilmstumor. What is the stage of Wilm's tumor in this child?
questions.explanation: Wilms tumor with involvement of both kidneys is stage 5.Children's Oncology Group (COG) Staging System686Stage IStage IIStage IIIStage IVStageVTumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins andlymph nodes.Residual tumor present following surgery confined to theabdomen, including gross ormicroscopic tumor.Hematogenous metastases (1ung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)or lymph node metastases outside the abdominopelvic regionMetastasis to opposite kidney(bilateral renal involvement)

questions.question: While posted in the pediatric oncology ward, you come across a case of metastatic triphasicnephroblastoma in a 4-year-old. What is the most common site for metastasis of this tumor?
questions.explanation: The most common sites for metastases of nephroblastoma or Wilms tumor are the following:•Lungs (Most common)•• Regional lymph nodes• LiverThe triphasic components visualized on histopathology are-••Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).⚫ Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).⚫ Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)687Wilms Tumor/Triphasic NephroblastomaOMARROW

questions.question: What is the most important determinant of prognosis in a child diagnosed with Wilm'stumor?

options.B: Loss of heterozygosity of chromosome 1 p672

questions.explanation: Histology is the most important determinant of prognosis in Wilm's Tumor. The absence ofanaplasia is considered a favorable histological finding.Other prognostic factors for risk-adapted therapy include•Age• Stage•Tumor weight• Loss of heterozygosity at chromosomes 1p and 16q.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child comes with abdominal distension, a palpable mass, and gross hematuria. Abiopsy of the mass shows the following picture. Which of the following paraneoplasticsyndromes in not associated with this tumor?
questions.explanation: The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components of Wilm's tumor.Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy is not a paraneoplastic syndrome of Wilm's tumor.Several distinct paraneoplastic syndromes have been reported in Wilm's tumor. They are asfollows:••HypertensionErythrocytosis/Polycythemia• Hypercalcemia• Cushing syndrome• Acquired von Willebrand disease688Bleeding may occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome in Wilm's tumor. It is due to acquireddeficiency of von Willebrand factor or factor VII deficiency.The triphasic components visualized on histopathology are-• Malignant small round (blue) cells (blastemal component).•Tubular structures/rosettes (epithelial component).• Loose pauci-cellular stroma with spindle cells (stromal component)Wilms Tumor/Triphasic Nephroblastoma©MARROW

questions.question: The most common soft tissue sarcoma in the pediatric age group is
questions.explanation: Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, is the most common pediatric soft tissuesarcoma.The most common sites are- head and neck (25%) > genitourinary tract (24%) > extremities(19%) > orbit (9%).

questions.question: 673A 4-year-old girl presents with the lesion shown in this picture. The diagnosis is
questions.explanation: The lesion seen in the picture is sarcoma botryoidesVaginal rhabdomyosarcoma may manifest as a grape-like mass of tumor tissue bulging throughthe vaginal orifice, known as sarcoma botryoides.

questions.question: The precursor lesion of Wilm's tumor is
questions.explanation: • Wilms tumor is derived from foci of incompletely differentiated/undifferentiated renalmesenchyme called nephrogenic rests.689•Nephrogenic rests usually regress or differentiate, but those that persist can become malignant.• Nephrogenic rests that persist abnormally in the kidneys into postnatal life are seen in 1% ofchildren in the general population, but are seen in up to 90% of children who develop or have afamily history of Wilms tumor.

questions.question: The term "trilateral retinoblastoma" refers to bilateral retinoblastoma +
questions.explanation: A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called “trilateralretinoblastoma."In hereditary retinoblastoma (having spontaneous germline RB1 mutation), second malignanciesare a major concern. The most common second malignancy is osteosarcoma; other secondneoplasms include rhabdomyosarcoma and melanoma.

questions.question: Tumor which may undergo spontaneous regression is
questions.explanation: Neuroblastoma is an embryonal cancer of the peripheral sympathetic nervous system withheterogeneous presentation and prognosis; some tumors may undergo spontaneous regression,whereas some may be unresponsive to therapy and run a very aggressive course.

questions.question: Which of the following pediatric tumors is called a "triphasic" blastoma?
questions.explanation: • The classic nephroblastoma, aka Wilms tumor, is a mixed tumor (more than one neoplastic celltype) derived from one germ-cell layer (examples: Wilms tumor and pleomorphic adenoma ofsalivary gland).• Histologically, it is made up of the classic "triphasic" combination (recapitulating stages ofnormal renal development) of• Stromal•Epithelial, and• Blast cells690
